testimony: I beg your pardon.  We are commencing with the application of David Thejane and the Panel that would hear the same, it's myself, Motata chairing and my brother Judge Chris de Jager on my right.  We are both from the Transvaal Provincial Division in Gauteng.  On my left is our brother Adv Sandi from East London in the Eastern Cape.  I would request the legal representatives to place themselves on record.  I'll start with you Mr Johnson.
As it pleases the Committee.  I'm Henry Johnson from Henry Johnson Attorneys in Zastron Street here in Bloemfontein.
Thank you Mr Johnson.  For the victim?

As it pleases the Honourable Committee.  My name is S H Samuel, Hamilton Samuel, I'm from the firm N W Palat and Partners in Bloemfontein and I appear on behalf of the victims, Abel Coane, Norman Choane as well as well as Moiketsi Jikila.
Thank you Mr Samuel.  Mr Johnson, are you ready to start with the applicant and my I ask you ...
I am ready Mr Chairperson.  I will lead the witness in English, or the applicant in English as it seems as if it will be easier for everybody.
I'll ask my colleague here to swear the applicant in.
Is he Afrikaans or English speaking?
The applicant can indeed understand English, Mr Chairman.
Will he give evidence in English?
He's going to give his evidence in Sotho.
Mr Thejane, you are indeed the applicant in this matter, is that correct?

I'm going to lead the evidence of the applicant, Mr Chairperson, in connection - by the guidelines set in page 4 of the bundle, marked Annexure B, it is not a proper affidavit, but it is a statement made by the applicant.  Mr Thejane, you were a member of AZANDLA, is that correct?
Is it also correct that you left South Africa during 1985?
That is correct, Chairperson, that is in 1986.
And at that stage when you left South Africa, where did you go?
What were you supposed to do there?
I was seeking political asylum and going for training.
What training did you go for?
How long were you then in Botswana undergoing military training?
Where did you undergo this military training?
I started in Botswana, refugee Camp.
Could you again say what is the name of the camp where you underwent this training?
At what stage did you then return to South Africa?
In what manner and where did you then enter the Republic of South Africa?
I was arrested at Zeerust border gate.
Because I entered illegally, I entered Botswana illegally.
Do I understand correctly that at that stage you did not have any form of passport or something like that?
At the stage when you were arrested at Zeerust, where were you held in custody?
I was arrested at Zeerust police station by the South African Defence and the South African Security Police.
At some stage you were also then recruited by the Internal Security Unit known as Askari, is that correct?
Some black members came from Welkom and Sasolburg and then they came to me.
And where did they approach you?  Where were you at that stage when they approached you to recruit you?
They were not coming to recruit me, they were coming to take me, to arrest me at Welkom police cells and then give me papers of Section 29, of Internal Security Act.
Do I understand correct that at that stage you were held under Section 29 of the then Internal Security Act?
Could you describe how did it happen that you were then recruited to Askari?

They detained me for a year and some months under Section 29 and they were interrogating me.  Thereafter I was detained under Section 31, to testify against those who came from AZANDLA who were detained at Klerksdorp.
At the initial stage when you were then recruited, first of all did you then indeed join Askari?

They recruited me after I testified.  I was told by Gramor to come to Welkom after I was released to go and testify at Klerksdorp.  I was informed that people from Bloemfontein would come and fetch me there.
After you were recruited, what was your rank in Askari?
I was not issued with a rank, I met with the Commander of Askari, that is Capt Venter.
Is it correct then Sir, that in the initial stages you were only a normal troop, if you want to call it that?
Is it then also correct that at that stage by being a member of Askari, your force number was one of 0450085-7, is that correct?
That is correct, Chairperson.  I went to police college for training in Hammanskraal.
Is it also correct that at some stage you then occupied the rank of Constable?
Can you remember in which year it was which you received the rank of Constable?
What were the objectives of this group known as Askari, at that stage?
The objective was to gather information and again to track down people who had been trained outside.
At that stage, who were you commanders?
My first Commander was Sgt Barnard and after that it was Haberon.  Another one was Capt Venter and Sgt Botha came later.
In which area were you supposed to operated and then gather information?
I was working in various places, in Transvaal, Lesotho, Transkei and Free State as a whole.
The information which you then gathered, who were you supposed to give this information to?
We'd hand over that information to Sgt Barnard and then he would take it to Capt Venter and then he will take it to Col de Kock or to any person whom it is desired to be given to.

During 19 - apparently during 1991 there was an incident in Zulu Street in Rocklands where some shots were fired.  Would you please explain to the Committee what was this incident and what happened there?

It was at night.  I don't remember as to whether it was Friday or Saturday, I was having on my person a Makarov pistol.  There were people who were following me, there were about 14 to 15 people.  I produced the firearm and warned them, then I shot at them with the whole magazine.  I did not observe what happened thereafter.
Can you remember approximately in which month in 1991 it would have been that this incident took place?
I don't recall very well, but it was ...
Can you remember if it was in the summer or in the winter?
It could have been during winter time.
Now at that stage you say there were plus minus 14 persons.  What were they doing and what made you suspicious about this group of people?
I was disembarking an Opel Rekord car, they were following me.
What did you think they were going to do?
They ...(indistinct) me as whether they were armed with knives and ...(indistinct)
What did you think they were going to do to you?
I thought they were people who were instructed to come and kill me, or to kidnap me.
I saw the way they were approaching.
Now at that stage when you shot ... (inter-vention)
Sorry.  Sorry about that, can I just come in for a moment?  How were they approaching you?  In what manner were they approaching you which made you suspicious?
You said these were about - how many people, 14, 15, did I follow you correctly?
Mr Johnson I just want to have clarity on this.  Are you applying for amnesty in regard to this incident?
Chairperson, the amnesty application is indeed for this incident as well because he does not know if he at any stage, he injured anybody.

At this stage, I don't want to prejudge the issue, but it seems as though he's telling us now that he acted in self-defence.  He doesn't know whether he wounded anybody.  Is he admitting that he committed an offence here, because if he doesn't admit that he committed an offence, we can't give him amnesty.

Indeed, Chairperson, but this forms part of his affidavit which he gave to the Amnesty Committee in the first instance and that would form part of certainly a full disclosure, what he should be making to the Committee.  If the Committee does not wish to hear this evidence, I can skip that part and go indeed to the ...(intervention)

No, I don't know whether he's asking for amnesty for assault on people or attempted murder on people, or whether he's saying:  "well, I've done nothing wrong, I acted to protect myself."  If he's saying:  "I've only acted to protect myself", he could say that and we could leave it because then it's irrelevant as far as amnesty is concerned.  If he says:  "Well I exceeded the bounds, I'm asking for amnesty", then it's another matter.
I understand, Chairperson, and I will take it up with the applicant then.

You know, also in the same vein, I'm not sure if one can say there was any political motive on the part of these potential attackers on the applicant, it may have been a group of robbers who saw a potential victim and were about to attack him, we don't know.

On the other hand whether he had a political motive or whether he only wanted to protect himself, because if there was no political motive apart from whether it's an offence, it's irrelevant as far as amnesty is concerned.
Indeed Chairperson.  Mr Thejane, first of all I want to clarify one specific aspect.  At that stage you said you were in possession of a Makarov pistol.  This Makarov pistol, where did you get it?
It was issued to me from the Security Branch Office by Sgt Barnard.
Concerning this specific incident further, did you indeed then act in self-defence or is it something that you wish to apply for amnesty?
I don't know what happened after my shooting because I just returned to fetch the cartridges at night and early in the morning, so therefore it shows that no person was injured or killed.
I'm proceeding then to the further incident.  At some stage you were located or relocated to a farm outside Bloemfontein.  Can you remember in which year it was that you were located there?
Concerning this specific farm, what was this farm used for?
We used that farm as our office base.
During your connection, or during your period which you were one of the askaris, at some stage there would have been some tortures involving certain people, is that correct?
Can you remember when this would have been?
During that period when I arrived from 1990, 1991 to Sgt Barnard.
At some stage you were involved in the torture of one person by the name of Abel Choane, is that correct?
Can you tell the, or inform the Committee who is Abel Choane?
;   I learned that Abel Choane was one of those who were working at a particular unit and white members were not treating him well, then he ran away.
Is it correct that he was indeed - also formed part of Askari at that stage?
Could you inform the Committee how did it happen that Abel Choane was captured in the first instance?

The information came when we were in Ficksburg, when we were handling APLA members.  We received information around that Abel Choane is around Bloemfontein and Botshabelo.  We left Ficksburg and came to Botshabelo searching for him.

There was a certain member called Jack Baloi who left with an informer with Toyota Corolla, blue Toyota Corolla, to introduce Jack Baloi to that informer's uncle, that Jack is his uncle.  I did not know the content of that information.  Jack Baloi went with that particular informer and then we didn't receive further information but we followed that information day and night up to a point where, that is to say they had a photo album about people who we were supposed to identify.  We went to a particular teacher in Botshabelo together with Jack Baloi.  They went to a tavern which was called Peter's Tavern, it was a Friday night.  That informant introduced Jack to other people who were with him.  It happened that there was somebody who was sought for by Bloemfontein people,  Then Jack went outside to look for the photo and then he came to a kombi which was tinted.  I, Victor Gadi and Patrick Ngamela were sent to identify that particular person in the tavern.  We were given money to buy alcohol.  We drank about two to three bottles.  We produced the firearms and instructed all the people to lie down in the tavern, that's Peter's tavern, that is where we arrested Abel Choane's brother, who was known as Abel Choane, I don't remember his name but that person is from Welkom.  Abel Choane was not present there.  We took them and put them in that kombi which was covered with curtains.
Is that now Mr Abel Choane's brother which was arrested?
Where did you go to with them?
We brought them to  Fountain building at 5th floor.
That is correct, Chairperson, that is the Security Branch offices.
We took him because so that we will torture him so that he will tell us the whereabouts of Abel Choane because he was sought by Barnard and Company.
At the stage when he was then interrogated, were you present during this interrogation?
Were you also then involved in, or first of all this brother of Abel Choane, was he tortured as well?
That is correct, Chairperson, he was tortured and I was present.
In what way and how was he tortured?

He was interrogated first then thereafter he did not co-operate, Luit Landman instructed us to torture him, that was myself, Jack Baloi and Patrick Ngamela  We tortured him, we tied him with a bandage, his hands were at the back, we tied him on the legs.  We took a blanket, a sealing blanket which was used by detainees at the cells, we made him to lie down and we covered him with the blanket.  We rolled him so that he will face upwards.  Then somebody would sit on his legs.  I had a small tube.  I would cover him on the face with that tube up to a point where he would tell us the truth.
You covered his face with this tube.  Do I understand correctly that this person would then suffocate?
How many times, or - yes how many times was this person, this brother of Abel Choane, how many times was he tortured in this way, by putting this tube over his face?
I would say we did it five to six times.
And in each period, how long would this tube be over his face?

It would depend, because you'd feel as to whether that person is suffocating and those signs would tell us when to move the tube.  It may be some seconds to a minute.  We will see some sings, when you see him that he is suffocating, and then we'll move that tube quickly.
For how long in total did this period of torture go on on this person?
We started around 2 in the morning up to 4 o'clock in the morning.
When did you start?  How long did it last?  From 12 o'clock till 4 o'clock, or from what hour to 4 o'clock?
Did you receive the necessary information that you were looking for from this person who was tortured?
He informed us that he was together with his brother, but he did not know as to whether he went to Welkom, but he knew that he was around because he was with him.
Who gave you the instructions at that stage to torture this person?
We received the instructions from Luit Landman and Barnard.
And were they also present during these tortures?
Landman would be present, but I'm not sure about Barnard because we were many.
Is there any other way, except the tube which was used, which this person was tortured with?
Even by slapping him and hitting him with the fist.  Maybe other methods were used in my absence, I'm not sure.
After this person was tortured, do you know what happened to him?
I did not know what happened to him, Chairperson.
At which stage, or is it correct so that this person which you were looking for at that stage, Abel Choane, was also arrested later on, is that correct?
That is correct, Chairperson, we learned that he was arrested later.
And were you also then present during his interrogation?
I was present when he was interrogated and then again when he was tortured.
Were you also involved in torturing this Abel Choane?
Correct, Chairperson, I played a role.
We were slapping him.  If I remember well, we used the tube method to him.
Did you personally hit Abel Choane?
No, Chairperson, I did not but I used the tube.  I covered his face with the tube.
Now can you remember the date on which this incident would have taken place?
No, Chairperson, I don't remember the date.
And on whose instructions was Abel Choane tortured?
By Landman and by Matsisa's instructions.
And were they also present during this torture of Abel Choane himself?
Correct, Chairperson, they were present, they came in and out.
;   Can you remember approximately at which time this torture would have started and at which time they would have finished?
I don't remember Chairperson, but it took a longer time.
Would you say it was longer than his brother's torture?
The method that was used on him, if I understand you correctly, he was hit with hands and with fists and you again used the tube on his face to suffocate him.
The person who was hitting him has since died, he was shot and killed, that is Oupa Mashile.
Now at that stage whilst he was tortured by being hit, did you do anything during that stage?
Can you remember how many times did you put the tube over his face?
It was not only me who was tubing him but that was done four to five times.
But can you remember how many times you did it?
I tubed him many times, but I recollect only two to three times.
Can you remember if Mr Abel Choane at any stage during or after this torturing actually bled?
After Mr Choane was tortured, do you know what happened to him?
I don't remember, I don't know Chairperson what happened to him but he was handled by people who were at ground floor.
You mentioned a person that was also present during Abel Choane's torture, by the name of Oupa Mashile, is that correct?
Concerning Oupa Mashile himself, Oupa Mashile was actually murdered later on, is that correct?  He was shot dead.
We learned that he was shot dead in Welkom.
Do you know how or by whom he was shot?

He used not to come to duty and then on the pay day he had a fight with Luit Landman telling him that he did not come to work regularly, he's going to deduct some money from his salary, then they had a problem, then Oupa Mashile said he's leaving the unit.  He did not stay for a long time because he had four to five taxis, so it seems they did not trust him.  After that we were informed that he was shot dead by MK members.  When we were preparing to retaliate, we were told not to go there.
Do you know if Luit Landman or anybody from askari itself, was involved in the killing of Oupa Mashile?
I did not know because I was scared by the dispute they had, but I had that suspicion.
The only thing you had was a suspicion, you did not know, you did not have any knowledge that anybody was involved, is this correct?
That is correct, Chairperson, it was a naked suspicion.
Sorry, can I just come in there?  You say as you were about to go and retaliate someone told you not to go there, who was that?
Landman and Barnard informed us that they said we should not go even to his funeral.
I'm carrying on to a matter where another person was tortured, a person by the name of Jikila.  Do you remember this incident?
I do remember this person, Chairperson.
Can you remember when this took place?
I remember Chairperson when it happened.
Just before we step off the previous one, how long after Choane left the police was he killed, six months, a month, a year, or what?
Approximately three to four, four to five months.  He was a taxi owner.
I'm carrying on with the matter of Jikila.  Can you remember when this torture took place, the date and the year?
I don't remember the exact date, it was somewhere in 1993.
This person Jikila, do you know if he was a member of any other political organisation at that stage?
I did not know him.  The people who came with information were those who were working ...(indistinct - mike not on) and one of them is Booysen Motsamai.
Now this person Jikila, where was he tortured?
He was tortured at Fountain Security Branch office.
On whose instructions was he tortured?
Can you remember what form of information you wanted to extract from him?
He was not alone, there were many people.  There was information which we received whilst we were working in Transkei, looking for Happy Mphahlele.
And is that the nature of the information which you wanted to extract from this person called Jikila?
It was not only about that particular issue, but it was also in regard to the people who were involved in the burning of the farm houses.
At that stage, can you remember how long Mr Jikila was tortured for, what period of time?
He was tortured approximately, or he was detained at Botshabelo police station.  He was fetched four times, then all those four times he was tortured.
Were you present at all of these incidents all four times?
That is correct Chairperson, I was the one who had gone to fetch him from Botshabelo Police station and bring him to Fountain police station.
And in what way was Mr Jikila tortured?
He was tortured by being hand cuffed and leg cuffed and covered with a blanket and hitting him with fists and being slapped.
Was he also tortured by means of this tube that was put over his face?
That is correct, Chairperson, I was the main role player in the tubing effort, so I did that to him.
Can you remember how many times did you put this tube over his face so that he suffocated?
After Mr Jikila was tortured, do you know what happened to him, was he released or not?
I don't know what happened to him because they were detained under Section 21, I think there were approximately 20 to 25 people.
Do you know if Mr Jikila at any stage suffered any physical injuries during these tortures?
Did you speak to Mr Jikila after this incident?
Did he recognise you as the person who tortured him?
That is correct Chairperson because he knew me even before.
Did you apologise to him concerning these incidents where you tortured him?
Yes, I met with him whilst I was going to the bank, then we had a discussion with him, then he said there's no problem.  We went to a radio interview.  He's a friendly person.
And did he accept your apology?
That is correct, Chairperson, he accepted my apology.

I refer the Committee to pages of the bundle, pages 11 through to 13, which would be the typed and hand-written statement of this person named Jikila in which he confirms that.  As it pleases the Committee.
Mr Choane, have you spoken to Mr Choane after this incident?
Is that indeed Mr Choane sitting across the room?
Do you wish to apologise to Mr Choane about what happened to him?
That is correct, Chairperson.  I wanted to meet him but I did not know where he was.
Would you apologise to him now whilst he's sitting there?
Do that please.  Tell him that you're sorry.
I want to tell Abel Choane that I am sorry.  May you please forgive me?  This was the political situation, we were forced and there was nothing to do.  Things have changed now and I am sorry.
Now then at what stage, or how did it happen that you were not a member of this unit Askari at the end of the day anymore?
There was a meeting at Vlakplaas where Eugene de Kock addressed us and he told us that the unit was being dismantled and they will organise that we get the packages.
And did you then receive such a package?
Is there anything else at this stage that you would want to bring under the Committee's attention concerning any violations of Human Rights which you want to apply for amnesty for?

Yes, I just want to know whether it's possible for the Committee to go to the farm where we used to work, just to point it out.  There is no farmhouse anymore, all the stores that were there have been broken down, but the farm is still there.

If the Committee would want you to show them, they will ask you to go and show them the farm, but is there anything else that you want to make public to the Committee concerning any violations of human rights?  Other people which you remember which were tortured or whatever?
Yes, there are many of them, I do not even know their names, as far as Transkei.
Were these all people that were tortured whilst you were a member of Askari?
Do you remember any other specific persons except Choane and Jikila, do you remember the names?
I do not recall their names, but I could identify them.
Can you remember approximately how many other people were tortured during your stay at Askari?
Many people of the PAC who were in Ficksburg and those who were here in Bloemfontein.

Concerning your application, I just want to make sure about certain points.  On page 1 of your application which I will show to you at this stage, you make mention in paragraph 8(b) that you were a constable from 1989 to 1993 with your force number, the date of 1989, is that correct Sir?
No, it is not correct.  We were still Askaris at that time, we had not yet been appointed.
Yes, but if I understand your testimony correctly, you only were recruited by Askari in plus minus 1991, around there, is that correct?

Those are the only questions to the applicant.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR JOHNSON
Thank you Mr Johnson.  Mr Samuel, any questions at this juncture?
Mr Chairperson, yes I do have a few questions, thank you.
Mr Thejane when was Abel Choane arrested by the Security Forces?
I do not know when was he arrested.  I don't know what do you mean by his arrest.

If I understood you correctly, you mentioned that you tortured him, or you were present during the torture after he was arrested and if my understanding is correct, that according to your testimony is after his brother had disclosed his whereabouts to be in Welkom.
I don't think he said his brother disclosed anything.  They tortured his brother for hours on and his brother said:  "He's somewhere around, I don't know where."
Probably in Welkom, but he never disclosed.
I beg your pardon Mr Chairperson.  When you tortured Mr Abel Choane, where had he been arrested prior to the torture?

I do not know what happened.  Information came up that Abel Choane was present.  We had been looking for him and we could not find him.  Who caught him, I do not know, who arrested him, I do not know.
Where did the torture take place on Abel Choane?
It was at Fountain where I was present, I do not know whether he was tortured anywhere else where I was not present.
Okay, let's concentrate on the time that you were present.  Can you remember the date that you administered this torture where you were present at Fountain Street?
I do not recall the date.  He was not the only person we handled, we handled many people.  I do not recall the date therefore.
Could you perhaps give us an indication which year was it?
If I recall, it could have been around 91,92, if I remember well.

Are you sure, this is the question I'm asking now, I'm asking on you know the request of Mr Abel Choane, are you sure you were ever involved in torturing him especially in the method that you described earlier on, that of tubing him?
I was present, yes and we could have been six, if not seven, some - together with white people and some were just standing not torturing.
You said it was around 1991 thereabouts that you tortured him?
Could I just confirm something with my client?
Mr Samuel, we would like to know, if you could assist us, do you agree with - does your client agree with what he is saying or is there any dispute and if so, what are the disputes?

That is what I'm trying to establish right now.  I've got a statement from my client, I'm trying to reconcile that with the evidence that has been given by the applicant.  He says he was tortured by the Security Police, although he cannot remember if you were present or not, but he denies every being tortured by way of tubing.  What do you have to say about that?
The people from the Security Branch did not use the tube method, the Askaris, we Askaris used that method.  Maybe he does not remember me because my hair was permed on that day.

Would you say the extent and the severity of the torture on that day could have affected him in such a way that even given the fact that he was the recipient of this torture by tubing, he wouldn't recall the person administering that?

He did not know us.  During that tubing he even mentioned the name of Oupa Mashile, he said Oupa Mashile saw him with his colleague in the kombi when they were going to Welkom.   He was telling those white people that Oupa saw him and Oupa never arrested him at the time when he was wanted, because I did not know him, I only knew him from a photo.
Mr Samuel, just for my own clarity, does the victim, your client, does he remembered being tortured by a person with permed hair?
That doesn't appear from the statement so far, but I can quickly establish that.
Was Mr Choane ever tubed by anybody,  because he won't forget that if he had that horrible experience?
Well my instructions are that he was never tubed, but he would like, with the permission of the Committee, to explain the nature of torture he was subjected to by the Security Forces.

We are at the moment hearing an application from this applicant about what he did wrong, so we're not hearing evidence about what other people did wrong, that was heard by the HRV Committee, but this man confesses that he's done something wrong and now it seems that he's confessing about something he never did, or never did vis a vis your client.
And again he's under cross-examination so we wouldn't allow that.

Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Chairperson, since my instructions are that my client does not - denies, it's not a question of not recall, he denies ever being tortured by that method of tubing, I cannot take this case any further, or this line of questioning any further than that.

I suppose this is a question that is outstanding.  Mr Thejane said that whilst he was tortured, he even mentioned that Oupa Mashile saw him, but never arrested him.  Would he confirm that or deny that, that he said that whilst he was tortured?
Well that particular statement is denied by the victim.  There is another statement that he said, but not that specific statement, but it is not quite relevant at this stage to these proceedings.

Thank you Mr Samuel.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR SAMUEL
I have a few questions Chairperson, thank you.
Mr Thejane, you have testified that you also tortured the brother of Mr Abel Choane, am I correct?
Are you also applying for amnesty in respect of his torture?
What was the political affiliation of the brother of Abel Choane?

I did not know him.  The person we sent infiltrated them and I was told that, or I learned that this person was a teacher.  Which organisation he belonged to I did not know but I knew that he was Abel Choane's brother.
What was the reason for torturing him?
The reason for torturing him was to tell us the whereabouts of his brother, because we had already arrested a person who was going with Abel Choane.
How would you say the torture of the brother of Abel Choane was politically motivated if you did not know his political affiliation?
I don't know, two or three of them were arrested from the tavern and we were told to torture him to tell us where Abel Choane was because Sgt Barnard and them wanted him.
I was present when they were arrested in the tavern.
Who identified them for the arrest to you?

I mentioned that one of our members infiltrated Abel Choane's brother and the other teacher and they introduced each other, "This is Abel Choane's brother, this is so-and-so, this is so-and-so."  Now this person went outside and he took a thorough look at a photo.  We had Abel Choane's photo and a photo of the other Welkom chap, so he went outside to take a thorough look at the photo and this person who was working with us then came to us to tell us.  Luit Landman said we should then go and verify.  We should buy a beer and we should be satisfied.  We should actually look where Jack Baloi was sitting and verify as to whether the person in the photo is the person who is inside.  We went inside, bought some beers, pretended to be drinking, we took our guns and we made them to lie on the ground and we arrested them.  We took them into the kombi.
You are also applying for the torture of Jikila, am I correct?
Can you give us all the methods that you used in torturing Jikila, what was done to him?

Jikila was arrested at his house.  We took him to the office.  We then moved them to the police station in Botshabelo.  The next day we took him to the fifth floor of Fountain building.  He was interrogated but not by us.  People from the ground floor asked him questions and afterwards they brought him to the fifth floor.  We wrapped him in a blanket and we tubed him.
Is that the only method you used to torture him?
He was assaulted with hands in between, like he was being slapped, but that was the main method of retrieving information from a person, that is the tubing method.

According to Jikila's affidavit on page 11, he states that he was severely assaulted by your group and that, to an extent that he suffered a broken rib.  Do you know how he sustained a broken rib if he was just slapped and covered with a tube on his face?
I do not recall a rib being broken, but he was severely assaulted, yes and even when I was out, I had left the room, the tubing would continue, but I do not recall the broken rib issue.
In his evidence-in-chief ...(indistinct) he was also hit with fists, I don't know whether - slapped and hit with fists.

I did not get that evidence Chairperson and he also has not mentioned it now because I was going to go further and ask him.
